awd_titl_txt: Prospective Elementary Teachers Making for Mathematical Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
What teachers know and believe is central to what they can do in classrooms. This study takes an innovative approach to documenting how teacher knowledge can be enhanced by incorporating a design experience into pre-service mathematics education. The study's participating prospective teachers will use digital and fabrication technologies (e.g., 3D printers and laser cutters) to design and use manipulatives for K-6 mathematics learning. The goals of the project include describing how this experience influences the prospective teachers' knowledge and identities while creating curriculum for teacher education. Also, because more schools and students have access to 3D fabrication capabilities, teacher education can utilize these capabilities to prepare teachers to take advantage of these resources. Prior research by the team demonstrated how the process of making a manipulative can support prospective teachers in learning about mathematics and how to teach elementary mathematics concepts. The project will generate resources for other elementary teacher education programs and research about how prospective elementary teachers learn mathematics for teaching. The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

The project includes three research questions. First, what forms of knowledge are brought to bear as prospective elementary teachers make new manipulatives and write corresponding tasks to support the teaching and learning of mathematics? Second, how does prospective elementary teachers' knowledge for teaching mathematics develop as they make new manipulatives and write tasks to support the teaching and learning of mathematics? Third, as prospective elementary teachers make new manipulatives and write tasks to support the teaching and learning of mathematics, how do they see themselves in relation to the making, the mathematics, and the mathematics teaching? The project will employ a design-based research methodology with cycles of design, enactment, analysis and redesign to create curriculum modules for teacher education focused on making mathematics manipulatives. Data collection will include video recording of class sessions, participant observation, field notes, artifacts from the participants' design of manipulatives, and assessments of mathematical knowledge for teaching. A qualitative analysis will use multiple frameworks from prior research on mathematics teacher knowledge and identity development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The observation that "people have been making things forever" (Halverson & Sheridan, 2014, p. 496) readily applies to the work of teaching. The canonical image of the Making movement invokes the activities of making, experimenting, playing, and sharing. And with the added component of digital design and fabrication technologies, there are opportunities to extend and enrich the teacher's role as a maker of tools for teaching in the 21st century. 

By designing a teacher education experience that enables prospective teachers of mathematics to use 3D design and fabrication technologies to make manipulatives for student learning, the Prospective Elementary Teachers Making for Mathematical Learning (TMML) project responds to the mission of NSF's Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) program by addressing STEM needs related to teacher knowledge, technology, and teacher education. 

Intellectual Merit.  The intellectual merit of this project stems from a constructionist orientation to teaching and learning and the proposal that new access to learner-centered design practices and digital fabrication technologies will lead to powerful innovation in mathematics teaching and learning. By leveraging the consequent possibilities, this project has generated new knowledge about the contributions that Making can offer for preparing mathematics teachers; for developing their technological, pedagogical, and content knowledge; and for authoring themselves as effective and agentive designers of mathematical instruction.

Broader Impacts. As technologies like 3D printing become more pervasive in schools, teachers whose curricular thinking has been informed by Making experiences will be well positioned to develop these experiences for their students and cultivate their peers' and students' 21st century STEM interests and capacities. Multiple iterations of Making experiences with prospective mathematics teachers (PMTs) have yielded the development of a viable curriculum module that has been made available for widespread use in mathematics teacher preparation. This module engages prospective teachers in an iterative design experience that has been shown to advance their knowledge for teaching through the digital design, fabrication, and evaluation of new physical tools for use in instructional situations. Additionally, a creative and collaborative design environment for the PMTs' Making has demonstrated its influence on PMTs' uses of knowledge during teacher education, to cultivate PMTs' identities as designers of mathematical instruction and as agents of curricular and pedagogical reform, and to alleviate the historic trend of anxiety that PMTs have suffered in relation to their understanding of mathematics and their acquisition of a student-centered, inquiry-oriented model of mathematics pedagogy.

The project employed a design-based research methodology to create a curriculum for teacher education focused on the Making of original mathematics manipulatives. We investigated and documented the efficacy of the curriculum through three iterations in a specialized mathematics content course with three different mathematics teacher educators. Through these iterations, we explored how PMTs learn to teach mathematics and how the experience informed their identities as designers of mathematics instruction.

Three research themes emerged:

  1. Prospective elementary teachers bring rich and various forms of knowledge to their activity of making new manipulatives to support the teaching and learning of mathematics. The Making experience has provided opportunities for PMTs to embed their developing distinct facets of content and pedagogical knowledge into the design of their manipulatives, influencing not only their experience as a Maker, but also the depth of their mathematical understanding. Additionally, by enacting pedagogies of care in conjunction with mathematical Making experiences, some PMTs experienced a shift in mindset that celebrated and re-centered marginalized individuals within the mathematical learning and Making communities.

  2. The Making experience affords PMTs the opportunity to integrate their facets of knowledge during authentic teacher moments. Our curricular module engaged PMTs in the complexities of navigating mathematical problem-solving tasks through multiple representations of ideas. As a result, PMTs emerged with deeper understandings of those ideas and a realization of the power of exploratory, tool-mediated mathematical activity on teachers and students alike. In turn, the Making experience supported practices like reasoning mathematically and persisting through the often-messy process of teaching and learning mathematics, and thereby served as a transitioning vehicle for PMTs between teacher preparation and practice.

  3. The reflective and participatory creative processes of the Making experience provides PMTs with an opportunity to remake personal relationships with mathematics and mathematics teaching rooted in exploration and creativity. We analyzed our PMTs' learning by observing changes in their discourses of mathematics, identity, pedagogy, and design. We found that the Making experience provided an effective venue in which to provoke all four of these discourses and that these discourses are actually intertwined. This finding further substantiates the claim that one's identity is as central to learning to teach mathematics as is their learning of mathematics, pedagogy, and design.

Through this research, the TMML project has successfully developed curriculum and supporting resources for other elementary teacher education programs that we make readily available through our website at teachermakers.montclair.edu.
